revision.text:
'''Alfred Lambourne''' was born Feb. 2, 1850 in [[Berkshire, England]] and he died June 6, 1926 in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. In the 1860s he and his family moved to the [[American West]] with the [[Mormon pioneers]]. He is best remembered for his paintings, but he also wrote [[Short story|short]] [[LDS fiction|fiction]] for Mormon periodicals.<ref>[http://www.askart.com/askart/l/alfred_lambourne/alfred_lambourne.aspx Crocker Art Museum Store] accessed Feb. 27, 2009</ref>
==Early life== Alfred Lambourne was born to William and Martha Lambourne in England. The family emigrated to America when Alfred was a child. They first settled in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] before moving to [[Utah]].<ref name="The Alfred Lambourne Pages">[http://db3-sql.staff.library.utah.edu/lucene/Manuscripts/null/Ms0462.xml/complete The Alfred Lambourne Pages] accessed Feb. 27, 2009</ref>
==Art and exploration== After arriving in [[Salt Lake City]], Lambourne took work as a scenic artist for the Salt Lake Theatre.<ref name="The Alfred Lambourne Pages" />
Lambourne traveled the American West with photographer [[Charles Roscoe Savage]], painting as Savage photographed.<ref name="The Alfred Lambourne Pages" />
Lambourne explored the [[Wasatch range]] with [[H. L. A. Culmer]], painting and naming features. He also visited [[Yosemite]], [[Colorado]] and [[Arizona]].<ref name="The Alfred Lambourne Pages" />
Lambourne and [[Reuben Kirkham]] "painted a series of large canvasses representing his journey from the eastern coast of the United States, to the [[Golden Gate]]."<ref name="The Alfred Lambourne Pages" />
He also accompanied [[Brigham Young]] to [[Zion Canyon]] and allegedly made the first paintings of the area.<ref name="The Alfred Lambourne Pages" />
Later in life he focused more on writing, sometimes illustrating his work.

Ludlow |title= Encyclopedia of Mormonism |location= New York |publisher= [[Macmillan Publishing]] |year= 1992 |isbn= 0-02-879602-0 |oclc= 24502140 }}
